snippet: About one in six New Yorkers go hungry, and food pantries and soup kitchens are reporting increased demand from people whose food stamp benefits were reduced last year.
abstract: Rachel L Swarns The Working Life column; latest federal statistics on hunger reveal one in six people in New York City were unable to afford adequate food supply throughout the year from 2011 to 2013; finds that low-wage workers are lining up with homeless and elderly at food pantries; notes such difficulties explain why people are not encouraged by economic recovery when they see no raises and continued loss of benefits.
lead_paragraph: About one in six New Yorkers go hungry, and food pantries and soup kitchens are reporting increased demand from people whose food stamp benefits were reduced last year.

headline.main: A Growing Economic Recovery Bypasses Low-Wage Workers and Their Tables
headline.print_headline: A Growing Economic Recovery Bypasses Low-Wage Workers and Their Tables
